The license designators used were derived from the licenses (title, version and content) according to standardized rules, as far as possible and reasonable. The objective of standardizations was pursued and abbreviations were largely avoided.
A special feature are licenses or terms of use that do not bear any title or name. For these terms of use, the identifier was derived from content and context. In particular, simple permissions, which are common in many variations, are referred to here as "Permission Terms". In order to be able to classify and distinguish them more quickly, selected properties have been included in the license identifier (e.g. Permission Terms (no warranty; no advertisment)).
License information for components which are assignet to multiple licenses, which offer a choice or are provided with an exception, are presented in the form of an expression:
License identifiers or in turn license expressions separated by a comma (,), correspond to the conjunction with an AND.
Licenses or license expressions, that are linked with an OR or EITHER OR, are represented with a plus (+).
AND has priority over OR. A bracket replacement is only used if it is absolutely necessary for the correct representation.
If you assign the license expression Apache License 2.0, GNU General Public License 2.0 + GNU Lesser General Public License 2.1 to a component, this means that the Apache License 2.0 AND one of the two GNU licenses applies. When interpreting the OR, the license notes must be explicitly checked.
License assignments may have extensions or exceptions. These are represented by additions to the license identifiers. For example GNU Lesser General Public License 2.1 (or any later version) or GNU General Public License 2.0 (with classpath exception).
